Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12214
Section (1) An agency shall develop a written plan and implement the plan
Description to assure compliance with 1975 PA 238, MCL 722.621, and known
as the child protection law.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Foster care worker was made aware of alleged sex abuse of a
youth. The alleged perpetrator of the abuse reported this
information to the foster care worker. Foster care worker advised
the perpetrator to transport the victim to the grandmother’s home
as a safety plan and to call a complaint in. Foster care worker
never made a complaint to centralized intake.
Investigation A complaint was received on 2/8/23 stating Foster Parent A
contacted the Adoption Worker (AW) via telephone on 12/27/2022
to report that his adoptive son, Youth A, made allegations to the
adoptive grandmother that Foster Parent A sexually abused him.
AW instructed Foster Parent A to take Youth A to the adoptive
grandmother’s home as a safety plan and have her take him to the
hospital for a sexual abuse exam. Additionally, AW instructed
Foster Parent A to call in a complaint to centralized intake (CI) on
himself. AW failed to contact CI to report the allegations of child
sexual abuse that was reported to her. She also failed to report
the information to her supervisor.
Interviews:
The Complainant was interview via telephone on 2/8/23. During
the open DHHS Investigation it was discovered that Foster Parent
A still had an open foster care license. Foster Parent A told the
DHHS Worker he informed AW about the allegation against him.
He reported AW told him to call in the complaint to CI. The DHHS
Worker told the Complainant that she asked AW about this and
AW admitted that Foster Parent A did report the allegation to her
and she did tell him to call CI about it. Complainant reported she
also talked to AW and AW’s supervisor, Licensee Designee (LD),
about this. AW admitted to Complainant that Foster Parent A
reported the allegations to her and she did tell him to call CI. AW
told the Complainant that she was having a rough day when
Foster Parent A called. AW and LD admitted it is their protocol to
call in complaints to CI.
The Licensing Worker (LW) was interviewed via video conference
on 2/22/23. She stated she was the worker who licensed Foster
2

Parent A 3-4 years ago. On 1/10/23, she contacted Foster Parent
A to ask him about another issue when he told her about the
allegations his son made against him. She then called the DHHS
Worker and DHHS Supervisor about the allegations and to find
out why they never informed her of the allegations. During LW’s
conversation with Foster Parent A, he mentioned that he told the
AW and AW told him to report the allegations. LW contacted AW
who confirmed Foster Parent A told her about the allegations. LW
stated they are taught to follow the protocol of reporting incidents
of abuse/neglect. She said that protocol includes reporting the
allegations to CI if the allegation does not come from CI, complete
an incident report and let the supervisor know. LD is the
Supervisor. LW believes an incident report was completed.
The Adoption Worker (AW) was interviewed via video
conferencing on 2/22/23. She stated she is a Foster
Care/Adoption Specialist and has done this job for 8-9 years. She
reported Foster Parent A called her over the Christmas holiday
and told her that his son was alleging he sexually abused him.
Foster Parent A wanted to know what to do. AW told Foster
Parent A to see if Youth A would go stay with Foster Parent A's
mother, have him see a doctor and to call in the allegations to CI.
She then went back to sleep and did not think of it again until LW
asked her about it. AW stated she was at home sick when Foster
Parent A called. She said she knew if she had been well, she
would have contacted her supervisor, LD, to find out what to do.
She was not sure at the time what the protocol was for allegations
like this. She did complete an incident report once LW brought it
up. She said she has since been told she should have called in a
complaint to CI and called the agency simultaneously.
Licensee Designee (LD) was interviewed by telephone on 2/22/23.
LD reported she supervises LW and AW in her Foster
Care/Adoption work. She was informed of allegations on 1/10/23
from LW. She said she also found out AW knew about the
allegations prior to them being brought up to LW and then talked
to AW about it. AW apologized for not notifying anyone. LD
reported any allegation of abuse/neglect is to be called into CI,
documented in an incident report, let her know, and initiate a
Special Evaluation. There is a checklist for foster care/adoption
workers to complete when they go to licensed homes. On the
checklist it indicates staff are to contact licensing if there are any
issues in the home. She is not sure if AW was disciplined as she
is not her direct supervisor. She also reported DHHS never
contacted them about their investigation which is something that
3

they usually get notification of. She trains staff on the child
protection law when they are hired and again every 3 - 4 months.
Documents Reviewed:
• Provider File in MiSACWIS: There is an open Special
Evaluation on Foster Parent A regarding the sexual abuse
allegations. A social work contact from LW dated 1/10/23
indicated she was informed of the allegations from Foster
Parent A. That same day LW talked to AW about the
allegations.
• AW Employee file: AW was hired on 11/19/12. She
received a corrective action plan on 2/23/23 regarding this
incident. She met with her supervisor and was advised on
following the agency’s reporting policy. AW had mandated
Reporter training on 5/20/21.
• Compliance with Child Protection Law Policy: if a worker
suspects child abuse or neglect the worker shall
immediately contact CI. An incident report is to be
completed and submitted to licensing. Any major concerns
in foster homes must be reported to the supervisor.
• Incident Report: An incident report written by AW was
provided. The report was not dated but it did indicate the
same information provided during AW’s interview.
Analysis The Adoption Worker admitted she did not report the allegation of
sexual abuse as required by the agencies policy.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.

sir_summary.summary: A Special Investigation Report for Homes for Black Children substantiated that an Adoption Worker (AW) failed to report allegations of sexual abuse. The AW was informed by the alleged perpetrator (a foster/adoptive parent) that a youth had accused him of sexual abuse, and she instructed the parent to call in the report himself but did not make the mandatory report to Centralized Intake or notify her supervisor. The investigation concluded the agency violated its policy and state law requiring immediate reporting. The AW bears direct culpability for the violation, having admitted she knew the protocol but failed to follow it due to being off-duty and ill at the time of the call.
